title: SciViz
text: apa_line() function designed create line chart adheres APA 7th edition style guidelines, using ggplot2 data visualization. includes options adding error bars represent variability data, along customizable titles, labels, colors, making ideal producing professional publication-ready line charts academic contexts.
code: data("lineData1") apa_line(    data = lineData1,    x_var = "Time",    y_var = "Value",    group_var = "Group",    error_var = "Error",    title = "Example Line Chart with Error Bars",    subtitle = "Following APA 7th Edition Guidelines",    x_label = "Time (Units)",    y_label = "Values"  ) #> Warning: package 'ggplot2' was built under R version 4.4.2

title: SciViz
text: apa_bar() function designed create bar graph follows APA 7th edition style guidelines using ggplot2 R. provides customizable options adding error bars, titles, labels, groupings, faceting, making suitable generating clear, publication-ready bar charts academic presentations publications. Example 1: Depression Scores Treatment Groups  example visualizes depression scores time two treatment groups (Control vs. Treatment), including error bars represent variability data. bar colors differentiate groups, chart includes clear title, subtitle, axis labels, making suitable publication. Example 2: Imbalanced Sample (Exercise Duration)  example uses imbalanced dataset illustrate apa_bar() function may suitable visualizing imbalanced data. case, number sessions varies across activity types, distort representation data bar chart. Consequently, function ideal situations sample sizes unequal across groups, may lead misleading visual interpretations. detailed breakdown: dataset includes three activities: Running, Swimming, Cycling. activity four corresponding rows, resulting total 12 rows dataset. Session_Type variable, indicates whether session occurred Weekday Weekend, repeats six times activity. However, creates imbalance representation sessions across different activities. Specifically, six Weekend sessions activity type, four Weekday sessions activity type. discrepancy leads unequal distribution sessions across activity types. result, imbalance activities means bar chart represent activities equally. particular, number sessions activity type differs, lead misleading visualizations. imbalance key factor might make bar chart less effective specific scenario, may accurately reflect true distribution sessions across activities.
code: apa_bar(    data = barData1,  # The dataset    x_var = "Time",  # The time variable (e.g., Day 1, Day 2, etc.)    y_var = "Depression_Scores",  # The response variable (e.g., Depression scores)    group_var = "Group",  # The grouping variable (e.g., Control vs. Treatment)    error_var = "Error_Values",  # The error variable    title = "Depression Scores Over Time",  # Main title    subtitle = "Comparison Between Control and Treatment Groups",  # Subtitle for context    x_label = "Days",  # x-axis label    y_label = "Depression Scores",  # y-axis label    bar_color = c("black", "darkgrey"),  # Custom bar colors for the two groups    legend_title = "Group"  # Legend title ) apa_bar(    data = barData2,    x_var = "Activity",    y_var = "Mean_Duration",    group_var = "Session_Type",    error_var = "Error_Value",  # Specify the error variable    title = "Average Exercise Duration by Activity",    subtitle = "Comparison of Weekday and Weekend Sessions",    x_label = "Activity Type",    y_label = "Mean Duration (minutes)",    bar_color = c("black", "darkgrey"),  # Different custom colors for groups    legend_title = "Type"  )

title: SciViz
text: Network plots way visualize relationships different entities, entity depicted “node” connections shown “links” “edges”. means network graphs use matrices containing points either connected connected . (x,y) pair, “inital” point “target” point. points can format directed & weighted, directed & unweighted, undirected & weighted, undirected & unweighted.used many disciplines neuroscience, computer science, intelligence analysis, physics, biology, . Network plots used neuroscience variety ways, corresponding variety different ways analyzing data. neuroscience, numerous types matrices used network plots neuroscience research, common ones adjacency Laplacian matrices. Adjacency matrices used neuroscience represent pattern connectivity nodes brain. Degree matrices used describe number nodes connected node network. Lapacian matrices used neuroscience study neural networks brain connectivity. Network graphs can used neuroscience visualize relationships individual neurons groups neurons.  image shows network visualized regular network, small-world network, random network.Source  graph shows example network plot depicting differences brain connectivity control vs schizophrenia patients. Source Along different types matrices, also many different ways visualize corresponding data. Lapacian matrices complex graphing scope function. resources graphing Lapacian matrices check iGraph package Lapacian_matrix function. iGraph documentation also information structural properties graphs degree degree distribution vertices. graphing adjacency matrices specific needs, check iGraph package’s graph_from_adjacency_matrix function. interact_network_plot function designed allow researchers create simple network graph optional title subtitle. allow researchers create multiple network graphs able distinguish easily, since networkD3 package way add title directly. interact_network_plot uses R packages networkD3 htmltools.

previous_headings: Network Plots and Heatmaps > Network Plot
title: SciViz
text: one argument necessary, data, matrix data frame edge list format. congruence networkD3 package’s simpleNetwork function, data frame object three columns. first two names linked units. third records edge value. (Currently third column doesn’t affect graph.) initial_pt: column NUMBER initial point variable. Default 1 target_pt: column NUMBER target point variable. Default 2 linkDistance: numeric distance links pixels. Default 10. linkColour: character string specifying colour want link lines . Multiple formats supported (e.g. hexadecimal). Default “#666”. nodeColour: character string specifying colour want node circles . Multiple formats supported (e.g. hexadecimal). Default “#69b3a2”. opacity: Numeric value proportion opaque like graph elements . Default 0.9 zoom: logical value enable (TRUE) disable (FALSE) zooming. Default TRUE title: character string: title graph. Default “Network Graph”. subtitle: character string: subtitle graph. Smaller, lighter text title. Default “Exploring Interactions Relationships”.

previous_headings: Network Plots and Heatmaps > Network Plot
title: SciViz
text: interactive simple network graph title subtitle. want save graph stand alone html file, can run following code.
code: library(dplyr) #>  #> Attaching package: 'dplyr' #> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats': #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from 'package:base': #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union library(magrittr) library(networkD3) #> Warning: package 'networkD3' was built under R version 4.4.2 #simpleNetwork(network_data_test) %>% #saveNetwork(file = 'Net1.html')

text: example dataset provided package explore interact_network_plot function can . dataset, network_data_test includes 4 columns, therefore 2 sets network data one data frame. 13 rows random data. Columns 1 2 form “Neuron 1” -> “Neuron 2”. Columns 3 4 form “” -> “B”.

previous_headings: Network Plots and Heatmaps > Network Plot
title: SciViz
text: First, function creates interactive network plot using simpleNetwork function networkD3 package. , adds title subtitle using htmltools htmlwidgets packages .
code: #create network graph p <- simpleNetwork(network_data_test,                     Source = 1,                 # column number of source                     Target = 2,                 # column number of target                     linkDistance = 10,          # distance between node. Increase this value to have more space between nodes                     charge = -900,                # numeric value indicating either the strength of the node repulsion (negative value) or attraction (positive value)                     fontSize = 14,               # size of the node names                     fontFamily = "serif",       # font og node names                     linkColour = "#666",        # colour of edges, MUST be a common colour for the whole graph                     nodeColour = "#69b3a2",     # colour of nodes, MUST be a common colour for the whole graph                     opacity = .9,              # opacity of nodes. 0=transparent. 1=no transparency                     zoom = TRUE                    # Can you zoom on the figure?    ) htmlwidgets::prependContent(p,                             htmltools::tags$div(                               htmltools::tags$h3("Title",                                       style = "text-align: center; font-family: serif; color: #333;"),                               htmltools::tags$h4("Subtitle",                                       style = "text-align: center; font-family: serif; color: #666;")                             ))

title: SciViz
text: Heatmaps use color graphically represent relationships many variables observations. originated 19th century, scientists manually draw “pixel” grayscale.  Correlation heatmaps used neuroscience illustrate connectivity brain regions. often done taking electroencephalography data brain consequently plotting time axes, color demonstrating relative correlation values. example heatmap graph use analyses structural functional systems, using simulated data. Source  Unfortunately, data used make plots like real research labs classified due regulations data privacy, use mtcars demonstrate use package’s corrheatmap function.

title: SciViz
text: one argument necessary, data, matrix data frame. data must numeric order correlation values calculated. Optional arguments colors, n_colors, title, dend addition dendrogram rows, columns, . colors: vector 3 colors. color argument uses package grDevices colorRampPallete function, thus can take vector colors agreement valid arguments col2rgb. Colors can hexadecimal form, color name (listed colors(), positive integer , meaning palatte()[]. Default magenta (#ff00ff), cyan (#00ffff), yellow (#ffff00). n_colors: number colors created pallete colors argument. Default 20. Increase large datasets. title: string characters. Default “Correlation Heatmap”. dend: string; “row”, “column”, “”, “none”. Default “”. corrheatmap function uses packages corrplots gplots create correlation heatmap many numeric variables observations user desires. using large dataset, n_colors argument increased accordingly.

title: SciViz
text: corrheatmap function calculates Pearson Correlations matrix returns correlation heatmap new Quartz window title, color key histogram, axis labels, optional dendrograms.

title: SciViz
text: First, function creates correlation values plot. corrheatmap function calculates Pearson correlation coefficients. Pearson correlation coefficient common way measuring linear correlation. number –1 1 measures strength direction relationship two variables. 0 1 positive correlation, 0 correlated, -1 0 negative correlation. , creates color palette colors given colors argument. Finally, creates graph new Quartz window using grDevices.

title: SciViz
text: can specify want dendrograms rows columns, just columns, just rows, dendrogram. example dendrograms rows columns.  example dendrogram rows.  example dendrogram columns.  example dendrograms.
code: corrheatmap(mtcars, title="Correlations of Car Features", dend="both") corrheatmap(mtcars, title="Correlations of Car Features", dend="row") corrheatmap(mtcars, title="Correlations of Car Features", dend="col") corrheatmap(mtcars, title="Correlations of Car Features", dend="none")

title: SciViz

title: SciViz
text: Cornerplots often used astronomy understand distribution numeric variables. often used display results Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) simulations, used astronomers identify variables Gaussian distributions. methods likely familiar astronomers may using package, even aren’t sure MCMC simulation Gaussian distribution , ways utilize package better understanding data. Let’s look example dataset package, starcatalog. dataset information 8774 stars, might interested seeing relationships numeric variables dataset. can make cornerplot, using default settings. need specify dataset, function create requested graph.  plotted numeric variables dataset, bv_color, parallax, vmag 2d 1d histograms. 1d histograms shown purple show distribution variable x-axis, 2d histograms show paired distributions variables x- y-axes. , can see parallax right-skewed, also clear 2d histograms part , clumping data vertically downwards. can see possibly outliers data looking combinations bv_color parallax, data points abnormally high parallax, even though values normal range bv_color. Additionally, can see many points fall within range using colorbar next 2d histograms. example, examining just bv_color vmag, high concentration stars vmag value around six, bv_color value around zero. many ways can customize plots make better suit needs. example, want examine relationships two variables starcatalog, can specify . can also remove countor plot sits top cornerplot, change color kinds histograms. ggplot2 color can used change color histograms, color palette options taken colorspace package.  , changed graph histograms blue fill/palette, two variables displayed, contour removed. customization can achieved changing number bins contour lines. default number bins histograms 30, can adjusted number choosing. Similarly, default number contours 3. bins parameter adjusts number bins 1d 2d histograms, contourBins parameter used contour plot top 2d histograms.  example , harder see distributions many bins, sure change bins contourBins parameters get result happy .
code: cornerplot(starcatalog) cornerplot(starcatalog, varlist = c("vmag", "bv_color"),             palette = "Blues", fill="dodgerblue3",             contour = FALSE) cornerplot(starcatalog, bins = 50, contourBins = 5)

title: SciViz
text: scatterplots included package optimized work large datasets, can customized fit preferences. plots can used look two numeric variables relationship . must specify dataset, x-variable, y-variable.  example, can see large concentrations variable, relationship two variables. investigate variables dataset , can use grouping color variable identify relationship changed addding categorical variable mix.  Sometimes can hard make different colors graph, can also facet variable instead changing color points. example using variable graph .  Now can see hard see multiples , R, stars multiples! specify group color points default black color specified. customizable features graph include changing alpha opacity points, size points. size alpha default 0.5. example changing parameters changes graph, using graph ’ve creating. color parameter changed blue4, make points easier see white background.  , points smaller also less opaque, makes individual point easier see. parameters can customized liking, graph adequately displays information want capture.
code: scatterplot(starcatalog, x = "vmag", y = "bv_color") scatterplot(starcatalog, "vmag", "bv_color",              color = "multiple", palette = "Viridis") scatterplot(starcatalog, "vmag", "bv_color",              group = "multiple",              color = "multiple", palette = "Viridis") scatterplot(starcatalog, "vmag", "bv_color",              group = "multiple", color = "blue4",              size = 0.2, alpha = 0.8)

title: Create APA-Style Bar Graph — apa_bar
text: Creates APA-style bar graph optional error bars, customizable titles, labels, boxed legend title.

title: Create APA-Style Bar Graph — apa_bar
code: apa_bar(   data,   x_var,   y_var,   group_var = NULL,   facet_var = NULL,   error_var = NULL,   title = "Title",   subtitle = "Subtitle",   x_label = "X-axis Label",   y_label = "Y-axis Label",   legend_title = "Legend Title",   tick_labels = NULL,   bar_color = "black",   save_as = NULL )

title: Create APA-Style Bar Graph — apa_bar
text: data data frame containing variables visualized. x_var character string naming categorical variable x-axis. y_var character string naming numeric variable y-axis. group_var character string naming variable group bars (optional). facet_var character string naming variable faceting (optional). error_var character string naming variable error values (optional). title string plot title. subtitle string plot subtitle. x_label string x-axis label. y_label string y-axis label. legend_title string legend title. tick_labels vector custom labels x-axis ticks (optional). bar_color vector specifying colors bars (default "black"). save_as string specifying file name save plot (optional).

title: Create APA-Style Bar Graph — apa_bar
text: Returns ggplot2 graph.

title: Create APA-Style Bar Graph — apa_bar
code: # Example 1: Sample data for depression scores by treatment groups barData1 <- data.frame(   Group = rep(c("Control", "Treatment"), each = 5),   Time = rep(c("Day 1", "Day 2", "Day 3", "Day 4", "Day 5"), times = 2),   Depression_Scores = c(20, 22, 19, 21, 23, 25, 27, 26, 28, 30),   Error_Values = c(2, 1, 3, 1, 2, 1, 2, 1, 2, 2)  # Example error values )  # Create the grouped bar graph with error bars, bold title, and italic subtitle apa_bar(   data = barData1,   x_var = "Time",   y_var = "Depression_Scores",   group_var = "Group",   error_var = "Error_Values",  # Specify the error variable   title = "Depression Scores Over Time",   subtitle = "Comparison Between Control and Treatment Groups",   x_label = "Days",   y_label = "Depression Scores",   bar_color = c("black", "darkgrey"),  # Custom colors for groups   legend_title = "Group"  # Adding legend title )   ## Example 2: Imbalanced Scenario barData2 <- data.frame(   Activity = rep(c("Running", "Swimming", "Cycling"), each = 4),   Session_Type = rep(c("Weekday", "Weekend"), times = 6),   Mean_Duration = c(30, 40, 25, 35, 45, 20, 50, 30, 55, 25, 60, 40),   Error_Value = c(5, 7, 4, 6, 5, 3, 6, 4, 8, 5, 7, 3)  # Example error values )  # Create the grouped bar graph with error bars apa_bar(   data = barData2,   x_var = "Activity",   y_var = "Mean_Duration",   group_var = "Session_Type",   error_var = "Error_Value",  # Specify the error variable   title = "Average Exercise Duration by Activity",   subtitle = "Comparison of Weekday and Weekend Sessions",   x_label = "Activity Type",   y_label = "Mean Duration (minutes)",   bar_color = c("black", "darkgrey")  # Different custom colors for groups )  # Note: This example illustrates an imbalanced design, which may result in misleading visual representations.

what: Create an APA-Style Line Chart with Error Bars — apa_line
title: Create an APA-Style Line Chart with Error Bars — apa_line
text: function generates line chart following APA 7th edition guidelines. allows inclusion error bars represent variability data.

title: Create an APA-Style Line Chart with Error Bars — apa_line
code: apa_line(   data,   x_var,   y_var,   group_var = NULL,   error_var = NULL,   title = "Title",   subtitle = "Subtitle",   x_label = "X-axis Label",   y_label = "Y-axis Label",   legend_title = "Legend Title",   save_as = NULL )

title: Create an APA-Style Line Chart with Error Bars — apa_line
text: data data frame containing data plotted. x_var string representing name variable plotted x-axis. y_var string representing name variable plotted y-axis. group_var string representing name variable used grouping lines. Default NULL. error_var string representing name variable error values. Default NULL. title string main title plot. Default "Title". subtitle string subtitle plot. Default "Subtitle". x_label string label x-axis. Default "X-axis Label". y_label string label y-axis. Default "Y-axis Label". legend_title string legend title. Default "Legend Title". save_as string filename save plot. Default NULL, means plot saved.

title: Create an APA-Style Line Chart with Error Bars — apa_line
text: ggplot object representing line chart.

title: Create an APA-Style Line Chart with Error Bars — apa_line
code: # Example data for the line chart lineData1 <- data.frame(   Time = rep(1:5, 3),   Value = c(10, 12, 15, 14, 18, 8, 9, 11, 13, 14, 20, 22, 21, 23, 24),   Group = rep(c("Group 1", "Group 2", "Group 3"), each = 5),  Error = c(1, 1, 2, 1, 2, 0.5, 1, 1.5, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1)  # Example error values )  # Create the line chart with error bars and boxed legend title apa_line(   data = lineData1,   x_var = "Time",   y_var = "Value",   group_var = "Group",   error_var = "Error",   title = "Example Line Chart with Error Bars",   subtitle = "Following APA 7th Edition Guidelines",   x_label = "Time (Units)",   y_label = "Values" ) #> Warning: package 'ggplot2' was built under R version 4.4.2

title: Astronomical Cornerplots — astroCornerplot
text: Create cornerplots astronomy data unlimited number paired variables.

title: Astronomical Cornerplots — astroCornerplot
code: astroCornerplot(   data,   varlist = names(data),   contour = TRUE,   fill = "mediumpurple",   palette = "Inferno",   bins = 70,   contourBins = 5 )

title: Astronomical Cornerplots — astroCornerplot
text: data data frame. varlist character, list numeric variables create cornerplot histograms . defaults variables dataset. contour (optional) logical, specify whether overlay contour plot 2d histogram, defaults TRUE. fill (optional) fill color histograms, defaults mediumpurple. palette (optional) color palette 2d histogram scale, defaults Inferno. options available scale_fill_continuous_sequential function colorspace package. bins (optional) number bins histograms, defaults 70. contourBins (optional) number bins contour plot, defaults 5.

title: Astronomical Cornerplots — astroCornerplot
text: corner plot 2d histogram showing intersection variables regular histogram variable.

title: Astronomical Cornerplots — astroCornerplot
code: astroCornerplot(starcatalog) #>  #> Attaching package: 'dplyr' #> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats': #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from 'package:base': #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union  astroCornerplot(starcatalog, contour=FALSE, fill="mediumpurple", palette = "Purples", bins=40)  astroCornerplot(starcatalog, varlist = c("vmag", "bv_color"), palette = "Blues", fill="dodgerblue3", bins = 50, contourBins = 3)

title: Astronomical Scatterplots — astroScatter
text: Create scatterplots astronomy data, optimized large number points

title: Astronomical Scatterplots — astroScatter
code: astroScatter(   data,   x,   y,   size = 0.5,   alpha = 0.5,   color = NULL,   group = NULL,   palette = "agSunset" )

title: Astronomical Scatterplots — astroScatter
text: data data frame x string, numeric variable y string, numeric variable size (optional) size points graph. defaults 0.5 alpha (optional) transparency points graph. defaults 0.5 color (optional) string, color points. takes either variable dataset name color. group (optional) string, facet variable graphs. palette (optional) string, color palette points, color provided variable. defaults agSunset. see scale_color_discrete_sequential function colorspace package palette options.

title: Astronomical Scatterplots — astroScatter
text: scatter plot specified variables

title: Astronomical Scatterplots — astroScatter
code: astroScatter(starcatalog, "vmag", "bv_color")  astroScatter(starcatalog, "vmag", "bv_color", color = "multiple", palette = "Terrain", size = 0.2, alpha = 0.7)  astroScatter(starcatalog, "vmag", "bv_color", group = "multiple")

title: BarData1 — barData1
text: depression scores time two treatment groups (Control vs. Treatment)

title: BarData1 — barData1
code: barData1

title: BarData1 — barData1
text: data frame 10 rows 4 variables: Group character. Group: variable indicates treatment group participants belong.  two possible values:  Control: Participants receive treatment.  Treatment: Participants received treatment. Time character. Time: variable represents specific days depression scores measured.  includes five time points: Day 1, Day 2, Day 3, Day 4, Day 5. Depression_Scores double. Depression_Scores: depression scores recorded participant specified time points. Higher scores generally indicate severe depression symptoms. Error_Values double. Error_Values: error values (e.g., standard error confidence interval) associated depression score. help indicate variability uncertainty measured depression scores.

title: barData2 — barData2
text: dataset includes three activities: Running, Swimming, Cycling. activity four corresponding rows, resulting total 12 rows dataset. Session_Type variable, indicates whether session occurred Weekday Weekend, repeats six times activity. However, creates imbalance representation sessions across different activities. Specifically, six Weekend sessions activity type, four Weekday sessions activity type. discrepancy leads unequal distribution sessions across activity types.

title: barData2 — barData2
code: barData2

title: barData2 — barData2
text: data frame 12 rows 4 variables: Activity character. Activity: variable represents type exercise activity participants engaged . three activities : Running, Swimming, Cycling Session_Type character. Session_Type: variable indicates whether exercise session took place Weekday Weekend. helps differentiate type day participants chose exercise. Mean_Duration double. Mean_Duration: variable represents average duration (minutes) exercise session activity type session day. shows long, average, participants spent activity. Error_Value double. Error_Value: error values (e.g., standard error confidence interval) associated mean exercise duration. provide indication variability uncertainty reported mean duration.

title: Cornerplots — cornerplot
text: Create cornerplots numeric data using unlimited number paired variables. can use unlimited number variables, recommended use six numeric variables.

title: Cornerplots — cornerplot
code: cornerplot(   data,   varlist = names(data),   contour = TRUE,   fill = "mediumpurple",   palette = "Inferno",   bins = 30,   contourBins = 3 )

title: Cornerplots — cornerplot
text: data data frame. varlist character, list numeric variables create cornerplot histograms . defaults variables dataset. contour (optional) logical, specify whether overlay contour plot 2d histogram, defaults TRUE. fill (optional) fill color histograms, defaults mediumpurple. palette (optional) color palette 2d histogram scale, defaults Inferno. Palette options taken colorspace package. bins (optional) number bins histograms, defaults 70. contourBins (optional) number bins contour plot, defaults 5.

title: Cornerplots — cornerplot
text: corner plot 2d histogram showing intersection variables regular histogram variable. Please note function can take load, especially running five variables.

title: Cornerplots — cornerplot
code: cornerplot(starcatalog) #>  #> Attaching package: 'dplyr' #> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats': #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from 'package:base': #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union  cornerplot(starcatalog, contour=FALSE, fill="mediumpurple", palette = "Purples", bins=40)  cornerplot(starcatalog, varlist = c("vmag", "bv_color"), palette = "Blues", fill="dodgerblue3", bins = 50, contourBins = 3)

what: Correlation Heat Map with or Without Dendrogram — corrheatmap
title: Correlation Heat Map with or Without Dendrogram — corrheatmap
text: Calculates Pearson Correlation Matrix plots resulting correlation values heatmap color key, histogram, optional dendrograms.

title: Correlation Heat Map with or Without Dendrogram — corrheatmap
code: corrheatmap(   data,   colors = c("#00ffff", "#ff00ff", "#ffff00"),   n_colors = 20,   title = "Correlation Heatmap",   dend = "both" )

title: Correlation Heat Map with or Without Dendrogram — corrheatmap
text: data matrix data frame title (optional) character vector. Default "Correlation Heatmap" dend (optional) string: "","row","column","none". Default . color (optional) vector three colors. Default cyan, magenta, yellow.

title: Correlation Heat Map with or Without Dendrogram — corrheatmap
text: heatmap graph new quartz window.

title: Correlation Heat Map with or Without Dendrogram — corrheatmap
code: #Graph will open in a new Quartz window when the corrheatmap function is run #Here are some examples of how to use the function corrheatmap(mtcars, title="Correlations of Car Features", dend="row") corrheatmap(mtcars, title="Correlations of Car Features", dend="col") corrheatmap(mtcars, title="Correlations of Car Features", dend="both") corrheatmap(mtcars, title="Correlations of Car Features", dend="none")

what: Network Plot for Interaction or Adjacency Matrix — interact_network_plot
title: Network Plot for Interaction or Adjacency Matrix — interact_network_plot
text: Create interactive network plot data frame edge list format. Designed exploratory data analysis visualization adjacency matrices.

title: Network Plot for Interaction or Adjacency Matrix — interact_network_plot
code: interact_network_plot(   data,   initial_pt = 1,   target_pt = 2,   linkDistance = 10,   linkColour = "#666",   nodeColour = "#69b3a2",   opacity = 0.9,   zoom = TRUE,   title = "Network Graph",   subtitle = "Exploring Interactions and Relationships" )

title: Network Plot for Interaction or Adjacency Matrix — interact_network_plot
text: data data frame edge list format. means row specify link 2 nodes. two columns; one inital point, second target point. initial_pt column NUMBER initial point variable. Default 1 target_pt column NUMBER target point variable. Default 2 linkDistance numeric distance links pixels linkColour color edges, MUST common color whole graph. default #666 nodeColour color nodes, MUST common color whole graph. Default #69b3a2 opacity opacity nodes. 0=transparent. 1=transparency. Default .9 title default "Network Graph" subtitle default "Exploring Interactions Relationships"

title: Network Plot for Interaction or Adjacency Matrix — interact_network_plot
text: interactive network graph

title: lineData1 — lineData1
text: dataset contains time-series values across three groups, associated error values time point, enabling visualization trends variability time.

title: lineData1 — lineData1
code: lineData1

title: lineData1 — lineData1
text: data frame 15 rows 4 variables: Time integer. Time: variable represents time points measurements taken. values repeated group, time points range 1 5. Value double. Value: variable contains numerical values measured time point group. values represent metric tracking time (e.g., test scores, measurements, outcomes). Group character. Group: variable indicates group observation belongs. three groups example: Group 1, Group 2, Group 3. group five corresponding time points. Error double. Error: error values associated measurements Value variable. Error values represent uncertainty variability around measured values can used construct error bars line chart. might correspond standard errors, confidence intervals, forms variability.

title: network_data_test — network_data_test
text: network_data_test includes 4 columns, therefore 2 sets network data one data frame. 13 rows random data. Columns 1 2 form "Neuron 1" -> "Neuron 2". Columns 3 4 form "" -> "B".

title: network_data_test — network_data_test
code: network_data_test

title: network_data_test — network_data_test
text: data frame 13 rows 4 variables: character. Set 1 Initial point network plot. Format: "Neuron 1", "Neuron 2", etc. character. Set 1 Target point network plot. Format: "Neuron 1", "Neuron 2", etc. inital_test character. Set 2 Initial point network plot. Format: "", "B", etc. target_test character. Set 2 Target point network plot. Format: "", "B", etc.

title: Scatterplots for Large Amounts of Data — scatterplot
text: data data frame x string, numeric variable y string, numeric variable size (optional) size points graph. defaults 0.5 alpha (optional) transparency points graph. defaults 0.5 color (optional) string, color points. takes either variable dataset name color. group (optional) string, facet variable graphs. palette (optional) string, color palette points, color provided variable. defaults agSunset. see scale_color_discrete_sequential function colorspace package palette options.

title: Catalog of 8774 stars and some information on them — starcatalog
text: data frame 8774 rows 8 variables: name character. name star. alt_name character. alternate name star, applicable. vmag double. visual magnitude multiple character. indicates star part binary (W) multiple system (B). class character. class star. bv_color double. color star. parallax double. parallax star. spect_type character. spectral type star.
